And then the maroon student, the maroon section,
Everyone sitting in the rune section yelled back, rise, rise, rise.
Similarly, the tradition of a, quote, court trip, where all members of the Corps of Cadets
went in alternate years to the Aggie football games in Houston or Austin and Dallas or Fort Worth.
Hitchhiking, we're getting there by hitchhiking, riding the train or buses,
crowding into 10 to 12 youngsters into individual hotel rooms, sleeping on the floor at a friend's house, and or reaching their destination just as the march began for the whole corps headed down
Main Street in Houston, Congress Avenue in Austin, are the main thoroughfires in Dallas and Fort Worth.
In fact, I had literally prayed for God's help in finding a good faculty appointment
But had asked.
For his assistance.
And not sending me.
To either Baylor.

A&M
Prince up paragraph part of that.
Negative feeling.
Began to disappear.
What one of the major steps?
And the disappearance.
Of that negative feeling toward A&M.
Came with the appointment.
to the Aspirations Committee, a part of what was labeled the Century Study.
That study was the climax of a plan
instituted instigated by some key former students and others who yearn for A&M to become more of a pace setter in higher education first in the state and then possibly even at the national level.
One of the first steps in that dream
had been the recruitment of Earl Rudder as president.
But now the idea was for some people, a large number of people, faculty, staff, former students and others, to begin to dream of what the Agricultural Mechanical College of Texas could become
by the time of its centennial anniversary in 1976.
I was appointed to the Aspirations Committee, particularly to the segment of that group to look at Resident Instruction and Student Life, RISL.
In hindsight, it is pleasantly astonishing to note that I was just about the only junior faculty member in that group, which included all of the other key
campus leaders, deans, senior faculty member, directors, and the most recognized faculty.
As the junior person in the room, in years, faculty rank
and accomplishments, it was easy to understand how I became the secretary and note-taker for RISL.
Soon we began the routine to meet every Tuesday afternoon, almost every Tuesday afternoon, for 18 months.
As we tried to
plan our pathway many quote working parties quote were appointed to review specific topics including such notable issues as co-education
racial integration, admission requirements, the Corps of Cadets, intramurals, student life, campus housing, curriculum, et cetera.
At least one member of the RISL committee
served with each working party, so there was splendid collaboration and communication.
Paragraph.
Among the most interesting of those groups was the working party
that tried to understand more clearly the status of A&M as it was perceived by Texas high school students.
That group led by Bardin, B-A-R-D-I-N, Nelson,
a highly respected professor of rural sociology was able to survey almost all the high school juniors and seniors in a 32 county area extending from Conroe just north of Houston
in an arc up to East Dallas through East Texas, up through East Texas to the eastern edge of Dallas.
He and Harold Brown, one of Dr. Nelson's young colleagues who happen to live directly across the street from us on Bolton,
in the Eastgate area placed before these students questions which included inquiries about all of the eight major institutions in the state including SMU, TCU, Texas Tech, Baylor, Rice,
the University of Texas, TSCW, the University of Texas at Austin, and A&M.
They had to ask questions about all of the schools in order to gain access to the students.
who had no idea that this was an A&M effort.
They learned quickly that this survey quickly reflected the fact that the average student had a very limited knowledge of the academic areas offered at A&M.
other than agriculture, engineering, and veterinary medicine.
These prospective undergraduates were particularly unaware that majors were offered at College Station in the humanities, social sciences, business, education, et cetera.
They also were well aware that A&M required every student to be male and to serve in the Corps of Cadets for the first two years.
One young man, one anonymous young man, summarized his view in an unforgettable style.
When he wrote, no girls, no fraternities, no fun, dash, no way, period, quote.
On a far more positive basis, when the students were asked to identify the, quote,
most outstanding schools in the state.
They responded.
Their responses were rice.
72% of them identified rice as one of that trio.
Texas followed with 71 and A&M was third with 58.
Then there was a
surprisingly large gap to the number four choice SMU at 32%.
Thus, A&M had the great advantage of having a comparatively strong profile for quality, but the difficulty of a lack of perception of what it offered.
Another impressive result of the questionnaires was the overwhelming correlation between the students' class rank and other quality measurements and the absence
of any interest by that student in going to an all-male institution.
Perhaps that can be phrased better as the strong correlation between the students with high grades and class rank and their desire to go to a coeducational school.
They were not, the best students were not interested in going to an all-male institution such as A&M or all-female such as the Texas State College for Women.
Similarly, there was also a very clear link between the
achieving students and their lack of interest in anything that was compulsory are required.
Our SL work also caused us to look at A&M's official admission requirements and we learned that in fact those requirements included prohibited anyone with
quote, a felony conviction, quote, or a quote, communicable disease, period, quote.
Then, other than being white and male, each applicant had to have simply
a high school diploma.
There were no requirements of class rank, special courses and or admission scores.
Obviously,
That non-selective set of criterion permitted many students to enroll who were not well prepared for the rigor of college studies.
After many months of hearing working party reports, studying their findings, and trying to look to the future, the RISL group met.
And in what we later agreed was a truly unforgettable day, we voted on what our general recommendations would be in the aspirations report.
Meanwhile, we were teasing
our friends on the research and extension segment of the century study because it seemed to us that they simply had the easy task of recommending, quote, more and better of everything.
During our deliberations, we had long agreed that we were to keep all of the reports, our deliberations, and any tentative recommendations in the conference of the committee's meeting room.
Similarly, without agreeing upon such policy, we did not discuss with our committee colleagues our personal leanings.
One reason for that reservation
became obvious later when most of us admitted that we had feared we were the only one, that we were in a small majority of the committee who would vote in favor of change.
That apprehension proved to be without foundation.
when on one momentous day the RISL committee voted in what I believe, now recall, was a unanimous decision to favor
making the Corps of Cadets optional to admit women, terminate racial integration, broaden the curriculum into an increasing horizon of disciplines, and add
many more graduate and professional programs.
As that session terminated and we walked away, we seemed to reflect proud
and optimistic caution.
Dash, because we wondered what the true decision makers would recommend.
Another
vote we took was to recommend that the title of the Agricultural and Mechanical College be changed.
We had looked at other land grant institutions during the period of the century study and had invited
Individuals familiar with those institutions to come and give us the benefit of their experience and judgment.
These guests included.
Mark Eric Walker, the president of Pennsylvania State University.
and Dr. Derwood T. Verner, the number two man at Michigan State University, who had compiled a marvelous record at A&M in the class of 1940.
a native of Cottonwood, Texas, a small crossroads junction near Abilene.
He was Woody Varner to all Aggies.
And he described for us how what had been the Michigan State College of Agriculture had within
a decade and a half following World War II become Michigan State University, as it notably ascended in quality and fame.

As we reviewed the separate land grant institutions, we learned that a number of those schools had once been titled for their state, plus the words Agricultural and Mechanical College, and then became
the capital letter State University in their state.
Thus, we recommended that the title of the separate land grant school for Texas be changed from the Agricultural Mechanical College of Texas
to Texas State University, a title which we thought had worked, a shift which we thought had worked well in Oklahoma, Kansas, Mississippi, in comparatively recent years.
Being the secretary of the committee, it became my responsibility to actually write and phrase the committee's findings, report, and recommendations for transmission to the campus administration.
In that role, I was reporting to Dr. Wayne C. Hall, a marvelously talented scholar in plant pathology who was then the vice president for academic affairs and dean of the graduate school.
When we completed our report, we turned it in.

And we're a bit surprised to learn that instead of perhaps thousands of copies of the recommendations being made for statewide distribution, that there would be only four copies and they would be kept under very guarded and kept in very guarded privacy.

Within a few days, I was summoned, received a call to report to Dr. Hall, and he handed me a copy of the report, which he said had been read by President Rutter, who had annotated it and added a number of questions.
Dr. Hall then asked me to quote, revise the report to bring it in line with President Rutter's wishes and to get it back to him as soon as I could do so.
As I turned the pages, I noticed such statements as no way, hell no, where did you get this stuff?
can't do it.
Thus, with a troubled fear in my mind and deep concern in my heart, I returned to the vice president's office and attempted to tell him
but I could not in good faith make most of those changes.
He inquired why I could not do so, and I told him it was because President Rutter was disagreeing in most instances with the committee's subjective judgments.
which I verified might be incorrect.
But the committee did truly believe that unless we modified the policies of segregation, of sexual segregation,
unless we modified the power.
